title: Metcalfe Street (Ottawa)
text:
Metcalfe Street is a downtown <a href="arterial%20road">arterial road</a> in <a href="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Canada. It is named for <a href="Charles%20Metcalfe%2C%201st%20Baron%20Metcalfe">Charles Theophilus Metcalfe</a>, a nineteenth-century Governor General of the Province of Canada. It is a north-south route, operating one way northbound, providing a key thoroughfare from <a href="Highway%20417%20%28Ontario%29">Highway 417</a> (the <a href="Queensway%20%28Ottawa%29">Queensway</a>). In the late 19th century and the early 20th century, its homes included those of Ottawa mayor <a href="Thomas%20Birkett">Thomas Birkett</a> (306 Metcalfe, <a href="Embassy%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Hungary%20in%20Ottawa">Embassy of the Republic of Hungary in Ottawa</a>), Canada's lumber and railroad baron <a href="John%20Rudolphus%20Booth">John Rudolphus Booth</a> (252 Metcalfe, <a href="Booth%20House%20%28Ottawa%29">Booth House</a>), inventor <a href="Thomas%20Willson">Thomas Willson</a> a.k.a. <a href="Carbide">Carbide</a> Willson, and <a href="Alexander%20Campbell%20%28Canadian%20senator%29">Alexander Campbell</a>, law partner of <a href="John%20A.%20Macdonald">John A. Macdonald</a> (236 Metcalfe).
The southern terminus is at Monkland Avenue in <a href="The%20Glebe">The Glebe</a> neighbourhood. It proceeds north as a minor residential street until the Queensway interchange (exit 119). As it continues north to downtown Ottawa, Metcalfe Street detours to the east of the <a href="Canadian%20Museum%20of%20Nature">Canadian Museum of Nature</a> between Argyle Street and McLeod Street, then continuing straight until <a href="Wellington%20Street%20%28Ottawa%29">Wellington Street</a> where the road ends at <a href="Parliament%20Hill">Parliament Hill</a>.
Major intersections.
